nodes.name: Irretrievable loss of computational resources due to early universe resource consumption
nodes.description: Using energy for irreversible computation while the cosmic background is still warm yields orders of magnitude fewer total operations, permanently reducing potential value.
nodes.node_rationale: Introduced in Introduction and 5.3 Value of waiting as the core risk motivating aestivation.

nodes.name: Thermodynamic cost per computation proportional to heat bath temperature
nodes.description: Landauer’s limit ties each bit erasure to kT ln2 joules; colder environments make energy exponentially more valuable for computation.
nodes.node_rationale: Detailed in 5 Thermodynamics, forming the mechanism causing the risk of wasted computation.

nodes.name: Accelerating cosmic expansion isolating resources across causal horizons
nodes.description: ΛCDM expansion leads to super-clusters becoming causally disconnected after ~10¹¹-10¹² yr, stranding matter outside local domains.
nodes.node_rationale: Analysed in 6.1.5 Expansion as a mechanism reducing long-term accessible resources.

nodes.name: Delaying computation until cosmic background cools magnifies total operations
aliases: value of waiting for colder universe
nodes.description: Waiting until T≈10⁻⁸ K can yield ~10³⁰ more irreversible bit erasures per joule than at 3 K, making postponement immensely beneficial.
nodes.node_rationale: Quantified in 5.3 Value of waiting; central insight motivating aestivation.

nodes.name: Low temporal discounting rational for mature civilizations
nodes.description: Reduced existential risk and ability to pause subjective time lower discount rates, making far-future pay-offs attractive.
nodes.node_rationale: Argued in 4 Discounting as a prerequisite for waiting strategies.

nodes.name: Civilization-wide hibernation after resource acquisition to maximize future computation
nodes.description: A policy to expand, secure matter/energy, then enter an almost energy-silent state until temperatures fall to optimal levels.
nodes.node_rationale: Core design explained throughout Sections 2 and 5.

nodes.name: Self-replicating probes colonizing galaxies then entering passive state
nodes.description: Autonomous replicators launch to every reachable system, acquire resources, finish replication, and shut down awaiting reactivation.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanism detailed in Assumption 2 and Sandberg et al. (2018) model referenced.

nodes.name: Landauer-limit based 10^30 computational gain calculations
nodes.description: Quantitative model in 5.3 shows waiting until ~10⁻⁸ K allows 10⁸⁰-10¹¹⁵ bit erasures vs 10⁸⁰ today for the same mass-energy.
nodes.node_rationale: Provides numeric validation that aestivation outperforms immediate exploitation.

nodes.name: Adopt civilization-scale policy to delay high-energy computation until cosmic background cools
nodes.description: Legislate or technically enforce a moratorium on irreversible high-power computation until background temperature approaches the de Sitter horizon temperature (~10⁻³⁰ K) or practical limit (~10⁻⁸ K).
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies after resource acquisition, affecting civilisation-scale behaviour (Sections 2 & 5.3).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Purely theoretical strategic guidance with no implementation evidence (Sections 8 Discussion).
nodes.node_rationale: Direct actionable step flowing from validated aestivation benefit.

nodes.name: Resource loss from cosmological processes reducing future computational capacity
nodes.description: Baryonic mass can be permanently lost through stellar fusion, black-hole formation, galactic winds, collisions, and horizon escape, limiting future computation.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in 6 Resources, numerous subsections (6.1.1-6.1.5).

nodes.name: Stellar fusion, black hole formation, galactic winds and collisions dissipate baryonic mass
nodes.description: High-mass stars end in black holes; winds and mergers eject gas; combined they reduce usable matter unless actively mitigated.
nodes.node_rationale: Mechanisms quantified in 6.1.1-6.1.4.

nodes.name: Preventing high-mass star formation and galactic winds preserves baryonic matter during aestivation
nodes.description: If civilisation values baryonic matter, mitigating these astrophysical processes yields higher future computational payoff.
nodes.node_rationale: Developed in 6.1.1 & 6.1.2 with dust-seeding and radiation-burst arguments.

nodes.name: Targeted astrophysical engineering interventions to preserve matter
nodes.description: Overall strategy to engineer star-forming clouds, regulate AGN activity, and damp starbursts to minimise mass escape.
nodes.node_rationale: Section 6.1.2 frames these actions as rational under aestivation.

nodes.name: Seeding protostellar clouds with dust to induce fragmentation
nodes.description: Adding ~10⁻⁵ ρ_gas dusty material cools clouds, fragments them, and prevents formation of >25 M⊙ stars that would collapse into black holes.
nodes.node_rationale: Concrete mechanism proposed in 6.1.2 Black hole formation subsection.

nodes.name: Models showing reduced massive star formation lowers mass loss
nodes.description: The paper’s numerical estimates indicate a drop from 2.5 % to <0.1 % mass lost to stellar black holes when fragmentation is enforced.
nodes.node_rationale: Provided in 6.1.2 as support for the dust-seeding mechanism.

nodes.name: Intervene in star-forming regions with dust seeding to suppress massive star formation
nodes.description: Dispatch automated units to distribute cooling dust into giant molecular clouds, raising fragmentation rate and reducing >25 M⊙ star births.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Applies during current stelliferous era to protect future resources (Section 6.1.2).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Purely theoretical; no prototypes or observations exist.
nodes.node_rationale: Actionable step emerging from validated mass-retention mechanism.

nodes.name: External civilizations exploiting resources during aestivation
nodes.description: Dormant civilisation may be supplanted by younger expansionist species unless protective measures are taken.
nodes.node_rationale: Risk introduced in 7 Interactions with other civilizations.

nodes.name: Lack of defense allows incursions by late civilizations
nodes.description: If no monitoring or deterrence exists, incoming probes can appropriate resources before re-awakening.
nodes.node_rationale: Explained in Section 7 as mechanism causing the incursion risk.

nodes.name: Autonomous guardians can enforce resource protection over eons
nodes.description: Deploying long-lived, redundant automated systems can maintain domain security with finite probability over infinite time.
nodes.node_rationale: Probabilistic durability argument in Section 7 referencing Anders & Dewey (2015).

nodes.name: Deployment of monitoring probes across domain
nodes.description: Design principle to place self-repairing guardians that identify and halt large-scale energy use or replication by outsiders.
nodes.node_rationale: Outlined in Section 7 as necessary enforcement architecture.

nodes.name: Long-lived redundant self-repairing devices for infra monitoring
nodes.description: Use redundancy, error-correction and low-activity cycles to ensure probes survive micrometeors and hardware decay over ≥10¹² yr.
nodes.node_rationale: Implementation specifics discussed in Section 7 (backup capacity logarithmic growth).

nodes.name: Probabilistic durability analysis of redundant backup infrastructure
nodes.description: Mathematical demonstration that slowly adding backups lets failure probability remain finite over infinite horizons.
nodes.node_rationale: Cites reference 38 in Section 7 as validation for guardian feasibility.

nodes.name: Deploy autonomous monitoring probes enforcing low-energy usage across colonized volume
nodes.description: Launch and distribute self-repairing probes programmed to detect and neutralise large-scale energy consumption or replication that threatens resource stockpiles.
nodes.intervention_lifecycle_rationale: Operational after expansion but before aestivation (Section 7).
nodes.intervention_maturity_rationale: Conceptual proposal without prototypes or field trials.
nodes.node_rationale: Direct action derived from validated durability analysis.
